required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Antibody Response to Prophylactic QHPV Vaccine at 48 Months Among HIV-infected Girls and Boys
clinical_study.official_title: A Longitudinal Cohort Study to Assess Sustained Immunogenicity up to 48 Months to Quadrivalent Human Papillomavirus Vaccine Among HIV-infected Girls and Boys Age 10-15 Years in Kenya

brief_summary.textblock: Longitudinal observational cohort study and extension of the MISP ID: 38406 'immunogenicity and safety of quadrivalent human papillomavirus vaccine in HIV-infected pre-adolescent girls and boys in Kenya'.

detailed_description.textblock: We evaluated for persistence of HPV antibody by measuring titers to specific HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18 at re-enrollment month 24 , 36 and 48 months in addition to month 7 and 12, after initial vaccination. This provided data for immunogenicity among HIV-infected children for approximately 48 months after initial vaccination. We assessed decline over study intervals in HPV type-specific antibodies.

primary_outcome.description: Geometric mean titers for HPV type -6, -11, -16 and -18

secondary_outcome.description: Impact of HIV RNA viral load on HPV antibody response
Impact of immune status on HPV antibody response

intervention.intervention_name: Quadrivalent HPV [Type 6, 11, 16 and 18] L1 Virus-Like Particle Vaccine
intervention.description: Intramuscular injection with 3 doses of QHPV

biospec_descr.textblock: Serum samples for HPV antibody titer assessment HIV viral load CD4 cell count

study_pop.textblock: HIV-1 infected boys and girls who had received 3 doses of QHPV vaccine

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- receipt of 3 doses of QHPV vaccine
- participated in primary immunogenicity study
- consent/assent with parental consent for participants age <18 years
- willing to continue extended follow up for 36 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- decline consent

facility.name: Partners in Health Research and Development

clinical_study.keyword: HPV Vaccine, HIV infection, Adolescents, Africa
